title: Hong Kong exports shrink 7.3 per cent in September as US-China trade war continues to bite
text:
Hong Kong exports shrank 7.3 per cent in September year on year amid the raging US-China trade war, ending the third quarter on a sour note.

Exports dropped to HK$347.7 billion (US$44.2 billion) in September while imports slipped 10.3 per cent to HK$379.3 billion, resulting in a trade deficit of HK$31.6 billion, the Census and Statistics Department revealed on Thursday.

Even before the gross domestic product figures were revealed, Chief Executive Carrie Lam Cheng Yuet-ngor announced in her policy address last week that Hong Kong had already slipped into a technical recession in the third quarter. That meant the city’s economic growth had contracted for two consecutive quarters.

The year-on-year decline in exports and imports widened further from August when they were down 6.3 per cent and 11.1 per cent respectively.

Hong Kong has already slipped into a recession. Photo: AFP More

“Merchandise exports weakened further in September to show an enlarged year-on-year decline, reflecting the slack in global demand and heightened US-China trade tensions in that month. Most major markets continued to show subdued performance,” a government spokesman said.

“As the strains on global trade flows arising from a slowing global economy and various uncertainties, including the development of US-mainland trade relations, will likely persist for some time, the near-term outlook for Hong Kong’s merchandise exports remains challenging.”

In the third quarter, the city’s exports declined 0.4 per cent from the preceding quarter. The drop was 4.6 per cent in the first nine months of this year compared with the same period in 2018.

China and the United States are in the middle of drafting a deal after making “concrete progress” in many areas during their latest round of talks to resolve the trade war earlier this month, according to Beijing’s lead negotiator, Vice-Premier Liu He, and US President Donald Trump.

Trump said earlier that he and his Chinese counterpart, President Xi Jinping, might ratify the deal during the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation leaders’ meeting in Chile in mid-November.
